wikipedia_page.main: Robert Turnbull Macpherson (27 February 1814 – 17 November 1872) was a Scottish artist and photographer who worked in Rome, Italy, in the 19th century.

response: The work was in the Farnese collection by the 1650s. After passing through other collections in Rome, it was acquired by Robert Turnbull Macpherson. It was attributed to Michelangelo by the German painters Peter von Cornelius and Friedrich Overbeck in 1864. Initially the attribution was rejected, and it was accorded to the so-called "Master of the Manchester Madonna" which was itself later attributed to Michelangelo.
*Robert Turnbull Macpherson (1814–1872), Scottish artist and photographer who worked in Rome
* 27 February – Robert Turnbull Macpherson, artist and photographer working in Rome (died 1872)

In 1846-1847, Jameson and Gerardine traveled in France and Italy with the eloping Robert and Elizabeth Barrett Browning.  Near the end of this trip, early in 1847, Geddie met her future husband, Scottish artist Robert Turnbull Macpherson, in Rome.
